original_data.loc[original_data["Class"] == "L", "Class"] = 35

source.cf3c67b2:
fig, ([axis1, axis2], [axis3, axis4])  = plt.subplots(2, 2,figsize=(12,8))
plt.subplots_adjust(wspace=0.25 , hspace=0.3)

sns.boxplot(x='gender', y='Discussion', data=original_data, order=['F','M'], ax=axis1)
sns.boxplot(x='gender', y='VisitedResources', data=original_data, order=['F','M'], ax=axis2)
sns.boxplot(x='gender', y='AnnouncementsView', data=original_data, order=['F','M'], ax=axis3)
sns.boxplot(x='gender', y='RaisedHands', data=original_data, order=['F','M'], ax=axis4)
source.831860a0:
fig, (axis1, axis2, axis3, axis4)  = plt.subplots(1, 4,figsize=(14,7))
plt.subplots_adjust(wspace=0.6)
sns.swarmplot(x='gender', y='AnnouncementsView', data=original_data, ax=axis1, hue = "Relation")
sns.swarmplot(x='gender', y='RaisedHands', data=original_data, ax=axis2, hue = "Relation")
sns.swarmplot(x='gender', y='Discussion', data=original_data, ax=axis3, hue = "Relation")
sns.swarmplot(x='gender', y='VisitedResources', data=original_data, ax=axis4, hue = "Relation")

sns.barplot(x="gender", y="AnnouncementsView", hue="Relation", data=original_data, ax = axes[0,1])
sns.barplot(x="gender", y="RaisedHands", hue="Relation", data=original_data, ax = axes[1,0])

source.07983bbb:
fig, (axis1, axis2, axis3, axis4)  = plt.subplots(1, 4,figsize=(20,4))
plt.subplots_adjust(wspace=0.6)

sns.regplot(x = "AnnouncementsView", y = "VisitedResources", data = original_data, ax = axis1)
sns.regplot(x = "AnnouncementsView", y = "Discussion", data = original_data, ax = axis2)
sns.regplot(x = "RaisedHands", y = "VisitedResources", data = original_data, ax = axis3)
sns.regplot(x = "AnnouncementsView", y = "RaisedHands", data = original_data, ax = axis4)

#Plot relation between ParentAnsweringSurvey with School's satisfaction with the parent

source.f7a790fb: This again shows that students "raised by their mums" in this dataset are more actively involved in study-related works.
source.c0b67c09:
### Viewing the data for students' participation in study-related activities

Attribute Explanations:
* Raised Hands: how many times the student raises his/her hand on classroom (numeric:0-100)
* Visited Resources:  how many times the student visits a course content(numeric:0-100)
* Announcements View: how many times the student checks the new announcements(numeric:0-100)
* Discussions:  how many times the student participate on discussion groups (numeric:0-100)
source.a3c2cfc0: ### Viewing the demography data to get a basic sense of these students' backgrounds
source.228d6b48: No particular **normal distribution** of any of the four indicators above can be seen according to the graphs above
source.8299e0e9:
#### Plotting some correlations between data
The five variables involved are the four variables representing how active a student is. The fifth is the performance measure of a student.
source.4f465666:
#### Measuring the student's performance
The "Class" attribute has three values: L for total mark of 0-69; M for total mark of 70-89; H for total mark of 90-100

I converted the "L","M","H" values to numeric data, specifically the median of the the interval represented by each, in order to find correlations between numeric data columns.
source.ef255f33: #### Does the gender of the parent matter?
source.5f3f0d8d: #### Picked some relatively strongly correlated here
source.f483b17d: It seems that boys represented in this dataset are generally a bit more open to discussions, visiting resources, and raising hands. But the boys and girls showed similar behavior in terms of viewing announcments.
source.8a98e32f: At least for visiting resources, the students who have mum as their "parent" has done a lot more work, no matter what gender he or she is. Another observation is probably that most of these numbers are either pretty high or pretty low, without many being in the middle.
source.f1d311c4: From the pie plt above, we can see that more fathers than mothers are involved in the childrens education.
source.0d4fac05:
From the observations above, none of these variable have very strong correlation between each other.

Specifically, none of these factors seem to correlate with the actual performance of a student -- the correlation is very low.
source.260c549e: From the graph above, we can see that about 1/3 of the students come from Jordan, 1/3 from Kuwait and 1/3 from many other countries. About 55 students are born at different countries with their nationality.
